page.title: 01Scorborough and Arram
page.content: This area is sparsely populated. There are 2 villages, Scorborough and Arram, and several scattered farms. The land is flat and mainly used for arable farming. There are large glasshouses at Arram for horticultural crops. A few sheep and cattle (beef and dairy) are grazed in the area. Horses are kept for recreation. There are many small copses of trees which provide cover for game birds. In the extreme south of the area is part of the Army School of Mechanical Transport, Leconfield. the villages are a little way off the A164 road linking the 2 market towns of Beverley and Driffield. Most people are employed in agriculture, horticulture or related jobs. Primary school age children from Scorborough go to Lockington school and from Arran they go to Leconfield school.
